awd_titl_txt: CRII: CIF: Automated and Robust Image Watermarking: A Deep Learning Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Digital image watermarking refers to the process of covertly embedding information into a cover-image and extracting it from it the marked-image; it is used in various application areas ranging from covert communication to authentication to security. Although many handcrafted watermarking schemes are available, these traditional methods run into difficulties due to the limited scope inherent to manual design. To implement image watermarking which adapts to the demands of increasingly diverse application scenarios, this project aims to develop novel schemes based on ideas from deep learning (DL). Two major problems will be addressed, namely (i) minimizing the requirement of domain knowledge, and (ii) achieving robustness without prior knowledge. Outcomes of this project will contribute to a new generation of robust and intelligent watermarking tools that can support cutting-edge applications such as camera scans and secured Internet-of-Things device on-boarding. The integration of the proposed research activities into university curriculum development and other educational programs will contribute to STEM education at various levels. 

This project seeks to advance the state-of-the-art in DL—based image watermarking through the development of image watermarking schemes that achieve a robust generalization of watermarking rules without requiring information about labeling, the original images, or distortions. The research agenda is structured around two complementary research activities: (i) DL—based automated image watermarking with similarity measures of distance functions, discriminator classifiers, or metric learning; and (ii) DL—based robust image watermarking that explores invariant image latent spaces and automatic rectification. The schemes to be developed will be tested on different applications to confirm their practicality. These research activities are expected to advance our understanding of watermarking on a number of fronts, namely (i) how to design deep learning components (such as architectures and layers) and novel algorithms (through similarity measures) to fully generalize image features and functions for image watermarking processes; (ii) how to design DL components to achieve robustness to different types of distortions in image watermarking, without requiring prior knowledge or adversarial examples; and (iii) how these designs can enable various novel watermarking application scenarios and use cases.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The essence of the project, "CRII: CIF: Automated and Robust Image Watermarking: A Deep Learning Approach," revolves around the exploration and enhancement of image watermarking techniques through the prism of deep learning. The project unfolded through three pivotal aims, which not only fostered academic advancement, as evidenced by the publication of seven peer-reviewed papers, but also contributed to a broader societal and technological impact.

1. Automated Deep Learning-based Image Watermarking:

The first aim was to develop an automated image watermarking system leveraging deep learning algorithms. The endeavor culminated in the publication of three papers titled, "A Deep Learning-based Audio-in-Image Watermarking Scheme," "An Automated and Robust Image Watermarking Scheme Based on Deep Neural Networks", and "Padding Module: Learning the Padding in Deep Neural Networks." These contributions shed light on innovative methodologies to embed and extract watermarks within images, thereby enhancing data security and authenticity in digital media.

2. Robustness in Deep Learning-based Image Watermarking:

The quest for robustness drove the second aim, focusing on fortifying the watermarking scheme against various forms of manipulations and attacks. Our findings are encapsulated in two published papers: "An Automated and Robust Image Watermarking Scheme Based on Deep Neural Networks," and "Perspective Transformation Layer." Through these scholarly articles, we unveiled robust watermarking schemes that withstand adversarial conditions, ensuring the integrity and resilience of watermarked data.

3. Application Exploration:

The final aim embarked on exploring the real-world applications of our developed watermarking techniques. This exploration led to the publication of the papers "DLWIoT: Deep Learning-based Watermarking for Authorized IoT Onboarding," and "A Brief, In-Depth Survey of Deep Learning-Based Image Watermarking." These papers exhibit the potential of our watermarking schemes in facilitating secure IoT device onboarding and providing a comprehensive insight into the state-of-the-art deep learning-based image watermarking techniques.

Broader Impacts:

The broader ramifications of this project extend beyond the academic sphere. A significant stride was the release of our methods and code to the community via GitHub, promoting transparency, reproducibility, and fostering a collaborative ethos among researchers and practitioners alike. Furthermore, the project?s findings have been instrumental in the development of new course materials, thereby enriching the educational landscape in the domain of deep learning and digital watermarking.

In alignment with the NSF merit review criteria, this project has not only contributed to the advancement of knowledge through its intellectual merit but has also engaged with a wider audience, fostering education and resource-sharing in a realm where technological advancement is synonymous with societal progress. Through the diligent exploration of automated and robust image watermarking via deep learning, this project has carved a niche in bridging the gap between academic research and real-world applicability, embodying the essence of broader impacts as envisioned by the NSF.


Last Modified: 11/01/2023
Modified by: Xin Zhong
